selected_quotes: Learning to read as an adult reorganizes your brain more than expected, a new
Our first paper on how illiterates' brains change when learning to read out in Science Advances
Aprender a leer (6 meses) produce cambios neuroplásticos en corteza cerebral y en la conectividad funcional en el cerebro a…
Wow! Learning to read (for 6 mos) reshapes even adult brains. Imagine the impact on children's…
Study shows that literacy training of illiterate adults improves their brain function.

citation.abstract: Learning to read is known to result in a reorganization of the developing cerebral cortex. In this longitudinal resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging study in illiterate adults, we show that only 6 months of literacy training can lead to neuroplastic changes in the mature brain. We observed that literacy-induced neuroplasticity is not confined to the cortex but increases the functional connectivity between the occipital lobe and subcortical areas in the midbrain and the thalamus. Individual rates of connectivity increase were significantly related to the individual decoding skill gains. These findings crucially complement current neurobiological concepts of normal and impaired literacy acquisition.
citation.publisher: American Association for the Advancement of Science
citation.title: Learning to read alters cortico-subcortical cross-talk in the visual system of illiterates

author.name: Inside School Research
author.description: Reporter Sarah D. Sparks spent the last five years writing about federal and state education regulations. Now covering education research, she can most often be found with a double-shot mocha in one hand and the latest academic journal in the other. Join her in a discussion of the politics, personalities, and p-values in education studies, and help bring research out of the lab and into the classroom.

A study of illiterate adults from India reveals that learning to read heightened brain activity and caused more extensive brain reorganization than expected. The findings also shed new light on the possible cause of reading disorders, such as dyslexia.

facebook.title: Learning to read alters cortico-subcortical cross-talk in the visual system of illiterates | Science Advances
facebook.summary: Illiterate adults who undertook a six-month program of literacy training showed neuroplastic changes in the cortex as well as the occipital lobe, subcortical areas, and the thalamus, according to a new study published online on May 24 in Science Advances.
